Convexity

Convex set

A set S⊆Rn is convex if

x1​,x2​∈S,λ∈(0,1)⟹λx1​+(1−λ)x2​∈S

Affine hull

The affine hull of a finite set V={v1,v2,…,vk} is defined as

affV:={λ1​v1+⋯+λk​vk∣∣∣∣∣​λ1​,…,λk​∈R,i=1∑k​λi​=1}

Convex hull

The convex hull of a finite set V={v1,v2,…,vk} is defined as

convV:={λ1​v1+⋯+λk​vk∣∣∣∣∣​λ1​,…,λk​≥0,i=1∑k​λi​=1}

Polytype

A set P⊂Rn is a polytype if it is the convex hull of finitely many points in Rn.

Polyhedron

A set P⊂Rn is a polyhedron if there exists a matrix A∈Rm×n and a vector b∈Rm such that

P={x∈Rn∣Ax≤b}

The set P is the intersection of m half-spaces. Polyhedrons may be unbounded.

Half space

A half space is the set the cuts the space in two parts

{x∈Rn∣ai​x≤bi​}

Convex function

Suppose that S⊆Rn is a convex set, then a function f:Rn→R is convex on S if

x1,x2∈S,λ∈(0,1)⟹f(λx1+(1−λ)x2)≤λf(x1)+(1−λ)f(x2)
  • A function is strictly convex if the inequality is strict.
  • A function f is concave if −f is convex.

Note that linear functions are both convex and concave.
